questions.text: Stars can fuse elements up to iron-56 and release energy, but fusing elements heavier than iron requires energy input.

feedback.correct: You understand the binding energy curve and stellar nucleosynthesis limits.
feedback.incorrect: Consider the binding energy per nucleon curve and what happens beyond iron-56.
feedback.explanation: Iron-56 has maximum binding energy per nucleon. Fusion beyond iron requires energy input, which is why stars can't sustain fusion of super-heavy elements.

modelAnswer.text: True. The binding energy per nucleon curve peaks at iron-56. Fusion of lighter elements (H→He, He→C, etc.) moves up the curve toward higher binding energy, releasing energy. But fusing elements heavier than iron moves down the curve to lower binding energy per nucleon, requiring energy input. This is why stellar cores stop producing energy once they reach iron, leading to core collapse and supernova.

modelAnswer.text: False. Complete conversion of 2 grams of matter gives E = mc² = 0.002 kg × (3×10⁸)² = 1.8 × 10¹⁴ J ≈ 180 terajoules. The Hiroshima bomb released about 60 TJ. So 2 grams of matter-antimatter annihilation would release about 3000 times more energy than the Hiroshima bomb. Even 1/3000 of a gram (about 0.3 milligrams) would equal Hiroshima's energy release.

questions.text: GPS satellites must correct for both special relativistic time dilation (due to orbital velocity) and general relativistic time dilation (due to weaker gravity at altitude), and these effects work in opposite directions.

feedback.correct: You understand both relativistic effects on GPS timing.
feedback.incorrect: Consider how orbital velocity and gravitational time dilation each affect satellite clocks.
feedback.explanation: Special relativity: satellite clocks run slower due to orbital velocity. General relativity: satellite clocks run faster due to weaker gravity at altitude. Net effect: GR dominates, satellites gain ~38 μs/day.

modelAnswer.text: True. GPS satellites experience two relativistic effects: (1) Special relativistic time dilation makes their clocks run slower by ~7 μs/day due to orbital velocity of ~4 km/s. (2) General relativistic time dilation makes their clocks run faster by ~45 μs/day due to weaker gravitational field at ~20,000 km altitude. The net effect is satellites gain ~38 μs/day, which must be corrected for accurate positioning.

questions.text: The Higgs mechanism explains why fundamental particles have mass, but most of a proton's mass actually comes from the binding energy of its constituent quarks and gluons, not from the Higgs field.

feedback.correct: You understand the distinction between fundamental particle masses and composite particle masses.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what gives quarks their mass versus what accounts for most of the proton's mass.
feedback.explanation: The Higgs field gives quarks their fundamental masses (~10 MeV total), but the proton's 938 MeV mass mostly comes from the binding energy of the strong force holding quarks together.

modelAnswer.text: True. The Higgs mechanism gives fundamental fermions (quarks, leptons) their intrinsic masses. However, a proton's mass (938 MeV) comes mostly from the binding energy of quantum chromodynamics—the energy stored in gluon fields holding quarks together. The constituent quark masses from Higgs total only ~10 MeV. Most visible matter's mass comes from QCD binding energy, not Higgs masses.
